thread.title: Move your business to the centre of the web |
thread.title_full: Move your business to the centre of the web | The Australian

author: The Australian
title: Move your business to the centre of the web |
text:
The digital revolution has facilitated unprecedented levels of collaboration, powering the world’s largest companies.
Facebook, Youtube, AirBnB, Uber, Freelancer.com and peer to peer lending companies like Society One inherently rely on their customers and suppliers to shape their strategy and their future.
The success of such firms has placed a renewed emphasis on the concept of “business ecosystems”, something that Deloitte describes as;
Dynamic and co-evolving communities of diverse actors who create and capture new value through both collaboration and competition.
Companies need to see where they fit in this new value ‘web’. Smart companies are using tools and technology to keep in touch with customers, find out what they want and create new sources of growth. At the end of the day, however, business will always be about relationships.
The key is to network with customers and pick up what they want. That provides new opportunities for growth.
A good way to start is with customer surveys. Smart companies will use surveys to create new products, improve customer service and provide staff bonuses and pay rises. Major companies do this all the time. Amazon, for instance, constantly monitors customer preferences and acts on them. It doesn’t really matter if the customer isn’t chasing a particular product that Amazon has reminded them about. What’s important here is that the customer is left feeling connected to Amazon. Amazon has shown us that good customer surveys and regular interaction with customers can be highly effective tools for building sales and turning prospects and one-time buyers into loyal, repeat customers.
Lego’s Idea Portal encourages customers to suggest new products, seeding ideas and building loyalty. Source: Lego Source: Supplied
Lego picked up on the explosion in crowdfunding by creating its Idea Portal , an interactive platform where customers can submit their suggestions for new Lego products, but also vote for other’s projects. More than 10 thousand positive votes gets a product nominated to become a new toy.
Companies like Qantas, Dominos, Telstra, Optus, and Virgin Australia use Twitter regularly to keep in touch with customers and get their feedback. Monitoring social media sites like Twitter, Facebook and various blogs is easy and inexpensive. That said, the company needs to be prepared to take all sorts of feedback and handle it with good grace and humour. Basically, these are tools that allow the company to respond to issues in a proactive way. It’s about building connections with customers and showing them that you really care. Just one tip: don’t get too defensive.
How should B2B businesses, or those who supply major clients think about their collaborative opportunities?
In Deloitte’s “ Business ecosystems come of age ” report (PDF) the consulting firm suggests that companies should rethink traditional B2B relationships. They suggest;
Reimagining existing supply chains as “value webs” that enjoy greater autonomy and trust, learn and innovate together, and forge the sustainable models for success that benefit all those involved.
Deloitte cites the success of Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba, who acts as a facilitator to help small businesses to create their own supply chains, and IBM’s Supplier Connection, which acts as a platform to help large firms manage their connection to smaller suppliers.
Deloitte supply chain leadership survey. Source: Deloitte Source: Supplied
Industrial behemoth GE believes its future depends on its ability to innovate, and sees collaboration with startups as a method to achieve that. GE’s head of innovation, Beth Comstock, says “We’ve created a mechanism to not just invest with startups but also partner with them. You do experiments, small scale, so that you can learn your way through them. You go to customers talk about how to change together. With a startup, you say ‘let’s scale together.’”
Understanding how your business fits into the ‘value web’ might be a win-win for your customers, your suppliers and ultimately you.
